steps.title: Measure the length and width of the curtain.
steps.content: Measure the length and width of the curtain. Lay your curtains flat on a clean surface. Use a measuring tape to measure from the bottom of the header tape near the top of your curtains down to the bottom edge of the curtains. [1] X Expert Source Donna Serino Dry Cleaning & Alterations Specialist Expert Interview. 31 August 2021. Then measure how wide the curtains are across the bottom.

steps.title: Determine the measurements for the liner.
steps.content: Determine the measurements for the liner. Subtract 0.6 in (1.5 cm) from the length measurement and subtract 1.6 in (4 cm) from the width measurement to get the size of your liner. If you're hemming the liner, don't subtract from the measurements. Instead, you'll need to add 0.8 in (2 cm) to the length measurement.

steps.title: Cut the lining fabric.
steps.content: Cut the lining fabric. Lay your lining fabric on a clean flat surface and use fabric scissors to cut the fabric according to your measurements. If your curtains are wider than the lining fabric, you may need to sew together 2 lengths of lining fabric. To join the lining fabric, add 0.8 in (2 cm) to the width and sew them together lengthwise. You'll have a 0.4 (1 cm) wide seam in the middle).

steps.title: Attach the fabric to the header tape.
steps.content: Attach the fabric to the header tape. [2] X Expert Source Donna Serino Dry Cleaning & Alterations Specialist Expert Interview. 31 August 2021. Measure the header tape so it's as wide as your lining and add 2.4 in (6 cm) so you can fold over the edges at the ends. Cut the tape and lay it on top of your coated lining fabric so the tape runs along the top edge. Pin the tape in place and fold 1.2 in (3 cm) of the tape under at both ends. If you're using non-coated lining fabric that could fray, fold over 1/2 inch (1.3 cm) along the top of the lining fabric before you pin the tape in place.

steps.title: Sew the lining fabric to the header tape.
steps.content: Sew the lining fabric to the header tape. Use your sewing machine to stitch the lining fabric along the top of the header tape. Then move the fabric so you can sew the bottom edges of the lining fabric to the header tape. The lining should be securely attached to the header tape. If youâ€™re working with a thick fabric like canvas, use a heavy needle with a ballpoint for an easier sew. [3] X Expert Source Alessio Iadicicco Apparel Manufacturing Specialist Expert Interview. 16 June 2021.

steps.title: Attach the lining with the header tape to your curtain.
steps.content: Attach the lining with the header tape to your curtain. Hold both ends of the header tape and pull apart so the header tape ruffles and becomes the same width as the curtain.

steps.title: Hook the liner onto the header tape of the curtain.
steps.content: Hook the liner onto the header tape of the curtain. Slide the curtain hooks into the header tape and feed these hooks through the header tape on the curtain. Try to leave about 6 to 7 in (15 to 20 cm) between each of the hooks. The liner should now be behind the hanging curtain.

steps.title: Use a seam ripper to take out them hems on the curtains.
steps.content: Use a seam ripper to take out them hems on the curtains. You'll need to remove the hems from the sides and tops of the curtains, but not the bottoms. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Measure the length and width of the curtain.
steps.content: Measure the length and width of the curtain. Place the curtains flat on a clean surface. Take a measuring tape and measure from the bottom to the top of your curtains. Then measure how wide the curtains are across the bottom.

steps.title: Cut the liner according to your measurements.
steps.content: Cut the liner according to your measurements. Add 8 inches (20 cm) to the length measurement since you'll need to hem the lining fabric. Use fabric scissors to cut the fabric according to your measurements. If your curtains are wider than the lining fabric, you may need to sew together 2 lengths of lining fabric. [5] X Research source If you're not hemming the lining because it's coated fabric, don't add the extra length.

steps.title: Fold the bottom of the liner and hem it in place.
steps.content: Fold the bottom of the liner and hem it in place. Lay the fabric liner in place on top of your curtain. Fold the bottom end of the fabric liner under by 2 in (5 cm). Pin it into place so you can easily sew the hem across the bottom of the curtain. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Hem the sides of the curtain.
steps.content: Hem the sides of the curtain. Fold the sides of the curtain in towards the liner. You should be able to see where the old stitches were that you ripped out. Use your sewing machine to stitch along both sides to secure the liner into the curtain. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Fold the top of the curtain over and hem it in place.
steps.content: Fold the top of the curtain over and hem it in place. Fold the top 2 in (5 cm) of the curtain over towards the liner at the top. Sew across the top of the curtain where the old seams had been. The liner should now be securely attached to the curtain. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Consider using iron-on tape for a temporary fix.
steps.content: Consider using iron-on tape for a temporary fix. If you don't have a sewing machine and you need a temporary liner for your curtains, lay iron-on tape along the edges of the liner. Fold the curtain sides over the liner and iron them in place according to the tape manufacturer's instructions. Iron-on tape can make your curtains appear stiff, so try sewing the liner if you prefer a more natural drape. Most iron-on tapes won't be sturdy enough to support the weight of the curtains and liners, so only use this for very light fabrics.

steps.title: Select a thermal liner if you'd like to insulate your windows.
steps.content: Select a thermal liner if you'd like to insulate your windows. If your windows are drafty or thin, save on your heating and cooling costs by lining the curtains with a thermal fabric. The insulation will keep heat in your room during the winter while keeping out drafts from the window. It will also keep cool air from escaping during the summer months. Most thermal liners are made from cotton, polyester, or a blend.

steps.title: Buy blackout liners if you want to darken the room.
steps.content: Buy blackout liners if you want to darken the room. Blackout lining is made from a thick, stiff fabric that will completely block light from passing through to your curtains. It's a good choice if you want privacy or want to block light in a room that gets lots of direct sunlight. Blackout curtains will also protect furniture and rugs from fading.

steps.title: Select water repellent or resistant lining.
steps.content: Select water repellent or resistant lining. Consider the window that the curtains will hang in front of. If the window frequently has condensation, you should line the curtains with a water repellent or resistant lining. The liner will block the moisture before it has a chance to soak into your curtains and damage the fabric. [9] X Research source Try using water repellent or resistant lining on kitchen or bathroom curtains since these are high humidity rooms.

steps.title: Pick a plain cotton lining to add weight to thin curtains.
steps.content: Pick a plain cotton lining to add weight to thin curtains. If you aren't concerned about blocking light or insulating a room, use a standard cotton liner. [10] X Expert Source Donna Serino Dry Cleaning & Alterations Specialist Expert Interview. 31 August 2021. The weight of the liner can help weigh down light curtains so they hang better. The liner will also protect sheer curtains from sun damage. [11] X Research source Check the materials of the plain lining since some may be made with polyester and cotton. [12] X Expert Source Donna Serino Dry Cleaning & Alterations Specialist Expert Interview. 31 August 2021. The polyester will prevent the cotton from shrinking, if you'd need to wash the lining.
